5b44b157-f315-4054-9f6f-6900e94d40be.description: Earners of the Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day) Course Completion badge are prepared to utilize theory and hands-on skills in a variety of fiber optic-related roles within the communication industry. They have demonstrated an understanding of fiber basics and common hands-on installation, testing, and troubleshooting skills. Earners may utilize their acquired skills in a broad range of fiber optic communication design, installation, manufacturing, or maintenance-related roles.
5b44b157-f315-4054-9f6f-6900e94d40be.name: Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day)

alignments.name: ETA International - Fiber Optics Installer (FOI)
alignments.description: Successful completion of this course prepares students to sit for ETA FOI certification exam. ETA Fiber Optics Installer certification is designed for those working with both multimode and single-mode fibers.

alignments.name: BICSI Event Code
alignments.description: Event Code - OV-LIGHTBR-WA-0321-2 | Eligible for 30 BICSI CECs

badge_template_activities.title: Hands-on Cable and Splice Closure Preparation | Earners of the Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day) Course Completion badge demonstrate how to properly and safely prepare fiber optic cable for acceptance testing, splicing, and termination at ends and at mid-entry points.

Hands-on Fusion and Mechanical Splicing | Earners of the Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day) Course Completion badge can discuss and demonstrate various optical fibers, cables, cleaving tools, techniques, and disciplines associated with optical splicing. The learner demonstrates an understanding of fusion and mechanical splicing of optical fibers in temporary, permanent, and emergency restoration applications.

Hands-on OTDR Theory and Operation | Earners of the Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day) Course Completion badge demonstrate comprehension of OTDR operation, terminology, functions, and applications of the OTDR as it relates to testing fiber-optic links. Specific competencies include cable acceptance testing, monitoring splices and installed optical cables, and how the OTDR is used during maintenance and restoration work.

Hands-on Connectorization | Earners of the Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day) Course Completion badge are able to demonstrate proper connectorization of various connector types and optical fibers in the field. Specific areas of focus are connector styles, bonding techniques, cleaving tools, and termination methods including epoxy polish, mechanical, and fusion splice varieties. The earner will also understand related testing, cleaning, and inspection procedures and equipment.

Earners of the Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day) Course Completion badge have demonstrated knowledge retention by scoring at least 80% on a comprehensive course examination proctored by the instructor at the end of the theory portion of the class.

da8d8014-f7a4-4dbc-88ae-3847001db3a1.description: Earners of the Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day) Course Completion badge will also receive the Sumitomo Fusion Splicing Fundamentals completion badge. Recipients are prepared to utilize fusion splicing theory and hands-on skills related to topics such as splicer maintenance, equipment and fiber preparation, splicing and splice protection, estimated and actual splice losses, and how to troubleshoot and correct common splice errors.
da8d8014-f7a4-4dbc-88ae-3847001db3a1.name: Sumitomo - Fusion Splicing Fundamentals

badge_template_activities.title: Fiber Optics 1-2-3 (Four-Day)

Earners of the Sumitomo Fusion Splicing Fundamentals Course Completion badge have completed an in-depth introduction to fiber optic splicing with an emphasis on fusion splicing. The theory introduces them to various types of splicing, splicing equipment, maintenance, operation, and standards and industry performance requirements, as well as troubleshooting common splice errors.

Earners of the Sumitomo Fusion Splicing Fundamentals Course Completion badge have demonstrated hands on understanding of equipment maintenance, equipment preparation, and fiber preparation as it relates to fusion splicing. In addition, earners have demonstrated fiber preparation and splicing of various fiber types, tested actual splice loss and compared it to estimated losses on the splicer, and demonstrated proper application and quality assurance of splice protection sleeves.

938b5409-45dd-4e66-9dbb-6162bab6777f.description: Earners of the Advanced Outside Plant Technician badge are prepared to apply the theory and practical hands-on skills in a variety of fiber optic related roles within the communication industry such as technician, team leader, installer, maintenance, or engineer. They have demonstrated intermediate level competency and understanding as it relates to fiber terminology and technology, FTTx best practices, emergency restoration, and fiber characterization.
938b5409-45dd-4e66-9dbb-6162bab6777f.name: Advanced Outside Plant Technician

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the Advanced Outside Plant Technician badge have completed an intermediate level theory and refresher course that builds upon the fundamentals and skills learned in the pre-requisite foundational level course such as Fiber Optics 1-2-3 or FTTx for Installers and technicians. Areas covered include safety, terminology, trends in fiber optics, FTTx fundamentals, emergency restoration, and an introduction to fiber characterization.

Hands-on Station - Cable Preparation Earners of the Advanced Outside Plant Technician badge badge have demonstrated preparation competency on mid-entry cable of OSP loose tube cables, stranded cables, and their respective closures.

Hands-on Station Splicing Earners of the Advanced Outside Plant badge have demonstrated understanding and hands-on competency of single fiber mechanical and fusion splicing, ribbon splicing, splice on terminations, and connector testing and inspection.

Hands-on Station Loss Testing Earners of the Advanced Outside Plant badge have demonstrated competency in building LAN panels, span testing including channel and permanent link, and measuring insertion loss, reflectance, and return loss testing.

Hands-on Station OTDR Earners of the Advanced Outside Plant badge have demonstrated understanding of OTDR setup, interpreting OTDR traces and results, troubleshooting spans, and restoration practices.

c4336a21-183a-4981-942c-393a65fe795c.description: Earners of the OTDR & Testing Deep Dive badge are prepared to apply the theory and practical hands-on skills in a variety of fiber optic related roles within the communication industry such as technician, team leader, installer, maintenance, or engineer. They have demonstrated intermediate level competency and understanding as it relates to the theoretical and practical intricacies of preparation and testing of optical links.
c4336a21-183a-4981-942c-393a65fe795c.name: OTDR Deep Dive

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the OTDR & Testing Deep Dive badge have learned the theoretical aspects and best practices associated with preparation and testing of installed links through presentation and demonstrations to lay a solid technical knowledge foundation for the practical application of the hands-on part of the course.

Hands-on Station - OTDR Theory and Operation Earners of the OTDR & Testing Deep Dive badge have demonstrated proficiency in using an OTDR for maintenance and troubleshooting purposes. Specific focus is given to advanced trace analysis, accurate parameter setting, and understanding the capabilities and limitations of the OTDR.

Hands-on Station - Cleaning, Inspection and Optical Loss Testing Best Practices Earners of the OTDR & Testing Deep Dive badge have demonstrated a working knowledge of proper use of equipment to test, inspect, clean, troubleshoot, and document fiber optic components. Specific focus is given to fiber identifiers, VFLs, analog and digital inspection devices, and cleaning products to ensure optimum performance and best practices in the field.

58b6c47c-574d-4dd5-9ad0-145fc0218fb6.description: Four-day instructor-led course designed to provide useful technical knowledge of fiber optics relating to FTTx applications, as well as the skills needed to install and test the physical layer for active Ethernet and passive optical networks (PON). Students have gained practical knowledge and hands-on skill in all aspects of FTTx deployments including specific issues—such as testing splitters, WDM devices, measuring reflectance, and bidirectional testing—that are unique to FTTx network.
58b6c47c-574d-4dd5-9ad0-145fc0218fb6.name: OSP for Installers and Technicians

alignments.name: ETA - International Fiber Optics Technician - Outside Plant (OSP-FOT)

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the OSP for Installers and Technicians badge have completed a foundational level theory focusing on fiber optic fundamentals, Passive Optical Networks (PON, Active Ethernet (AE), and other related areas as it relates to installation, testing, troubleshooting, restoration, and maintenance. Other areas covered include safety, terminology, trends in fiber optics, FTTx fundamentals, and an introduction to fiber characterization.

Earners of the OSP for Installers and Technicians badge have demonstrated competency in cable preparation, mid-entry of OSP loose tube cable and stranded cables, and performed closure preparation, panel dressing, splice tray routing, and splitter installation of their respective closures.

Earners of the OSP for Installers and Technicians badge have demonstrated understanding and hands-on competency of fiber optic strip and cleave process, inline and pigtail splicing using fixed v-groove and core alignment fusion splicers.

Earners of the OSP for Installers and Technicians badge have demonstrated competency in upstream and downstream testing, troubleshooting, and identifying key test results in an FTTX network, as well as familiarity with various test equipment and limit values and how to properly document an FTTX installation.

Earners of the OSP for Installers and Technicians badge have demonstrated understanding of OTDR setup and use as it applies to the FTTX environment, interpreting OTDR traces and results (distance, loss, reflection), troubleshooting spans to identify areas or loss or failure, testing optical splitters, and FTTX restoration practices.

2b6d59ad-a1cf-4ae3-9daf-97b802918e7b.description: Earners of the Fiber Optics for Utilities Level 1 Course Completion badge are prepared to apply theoretical and application based fiber optic principles and practices to utility installations. Areas of knowledge span basic fiber optic theory, as well as common products, equipment, tooling used for installation and maintenance of aerial and underground utility applications.
2b6d59ad-a1cf-4ae3-9daf-97b802918e7b.name: Utilities Level 1 - Technician

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the Fiber Optics for Utilities Level 1 Course Completion badge have completed an in-depth introduction to fiber optics, transmission theory, optical fibers, cables, connectors, splicing, cable management, installation basics, underground, aerial, ADSS, and OPGW installation practices, optical testing, emergency restoration, standards and codes, and safety practices.

98415c6e-f8f1-4068-a839-95ac6986eaf8.description: Earners of the CFHP Course Completion badge gained fundamental theory of FTTH architectures, design, deployment, and operations in a variety of broadband fiber roles. Through a two-day instructor led in -person class, or a twenty plus hour online training program, they have an understanding of basic fiber theory, FTTH architectures and topologies, network components, design and installation best practices, as well as an understanding of loss budgeting, testing, and troubleshooting measures.
98415c6e-f8f1-4068-a839-95ac6986eaf8.name: Certified Fiber to the Home Professional

badge_template_activities.title: Completion of an intermediate level course exploring the fundamentals and key areas of FTTX applications, economics, bandwidth management, standards, network topologies, network components, cables, cable management, network design, and loss budgets. Exposure to fiber theory, cable and fiber termination, loss budgets, and testing disciplines are covered. This broad range of comprehensive knowledge prepares the professional for all aspects of deploying FTTH networks from a supervisory or PM role.

Earners of the Certified Fiber to the Home Professional course badge have passed a comprehensive course assessment exam to ensure adequate knowledge retention, as well as to prepare them to sit for the Fiber Broadband Association Certified Fiber to the Home Professional exam to earn the CFHP credential.

15008eec-2dad-40ca-8028-68518fc517a8.description: Three-day, instructor-led course covering fundamental fiber and network component information relating to the proper design of FTTH point-to-point and point-to-multipoint optical networks. In addition to home-run, centralized, and distributed topologies learners will have a deep understanding of the importance of customer take rate and density, economic node location decisions, the importance of splitter locations, termination techniques, installation methods and practices.
15008eec-2dad-40ca-8028-68518fc517a8.name: FTTx Outside Plant Design

badge_template_activities.title: Completion of a three-day instructor-led design course beginning with fundamental fiber and network component information relating to FTTH network design considerations and best practices for product selection and ideal placement for point-to-point, distributed and centralized split network options. Focus areas discussed are AE vs. PON, network planning, futureproofing, various design and deployment options, GIS, specifications, design steps, and the differences between dense and rural designs.

Earners of the FTTX OSP Design badge have demonstrated competency of proper design practices for various FTTH applications as they relate to low and high density areas, take rate, terrain, and efficient use of active gear, passive equipment, and utilization of available fibers while maintaining a defined budget. The theory and hands-on activities of this class prepare the learner to sit for and pass the FBA OSP Design credential exam.

546c4232-148e-420c-87b2-0db29ddd0f6b.description: Earners of the Fiber Optics for Utilities Level 2 Course Completion badge have completed a one-day intermediate level course on fiber optics system design with a utilities focus. The course is aimed at personnel involved with the design, operation, administration, and management of utilities based fiber optic networks.
546c4232-148e-420c-87b2-0db29ddd0f6b.name: Utilities Level 2 - Designer

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the Fiber Optics for Utilities Level 2 Course Completion badge have completed and in-depth theory exposure to design parameters, cable management, route planning testing, and safety. Key subject areas include, specifying cables and terminations, installation planning and system design, loss budgets and testing, as well as a focus on switchyards and substations.

a2d5b451-e65e-4b8a-92cc-acbc660e13ad.description: Earners of the Emergency Restoration badge are are prepared to apply the theory and practical hands-on skills in a variety of fiber optic related roles within the communication industry such as technician, team leader, installer, maintenance, or engineer. They have demonstrated intermediate level competency and understanding as it relates to fault finding, troubleshooting, and field restoration to remedy outages.
a2d5b451-e65e-4b8a-92cc-acbc660e13ad.name: Emergency Restoration

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the Emergency Restoration badge have completed a comprehensive course that couples theory along with an emphasis on hands-on training that simulates actual field restorations for both retrievable and non-retrievable slack scenarios. The theoretical part of the course is broken down into Optical Network Failures, Identifying and Locating, Proper Planning, and Post Restoration.

Hands-on Station - Build a Network Earners of the Emergency Restoration badge have built upon their knowledge of network construction and have fabricated a fiber optic system comprised of two panels, one closure, and 200' of cable.

Hands-on Station - Build an Emergency Restoration Kit Earners of the Emergency Restoration badge have applied the knowledge obtained in the planning module to construct an emergency restoration kit containing a splice case, 100' of cable, and consumables to prepare for the inevitable.

Hands-on Station - Test and Repair a Failed Network Earners of the Emergency Restoration badge have demonstrated proficiency in identifying faults, damage, and other contributors to degraded performance or network outages. Using their previously built restoration kit and network, the earners have properly tested and where required have identified faults in need of repair. Using the restoration kit they are able to make an emergency repair to their network and verify performance.

ff0588c5-f421-4fb2-8771-120e3a497851.description: Earners of the Fiber Optics for Utilities Level 3 Course Completion badge have completed a one-day advanced level course as it pertains to xWDM system design considerations and advanced testing parameters including dispersion that can limit operating rates adn bandwidth on high performance systems.
ff0588c5-f421-4fb2-8771-120e3a497851.name: Utilities Level 3 - Advanced Designer

badge_template_activities.title: Earners of the Fiber Optics for Utilities Level 3 Course Completion badge have completed an in-depth theory exposure to advanced design subjects focusing on system performance and technology capabilities. Learners build upon their previous knowledge with a deeper dive into optical theory, components, multiplexing, dispersion, regeneration, advanced testing analysis, a look into the future, and others.
